title: The Soul
subject: Astral Metempsychosis
content: Astronomy compels the soul to look upward, and leads us from this world to another.

title: Discipline
subject: Divine Revolutions
content: The strongest affection and utmost zeal should, I think, promote the studies concerned with the most beautiful objects. This is the discipline that deals with the universe's divine revolutions, the stars' motions, sizes, distances, risings and settings . . . for what is more beautiful than heaven?

title: Spots
subject: The Vastness
content: Do not look at stars as bright spots only. Try to take in the vastness of the universe.

title: Colors
subject: Enjoyment
content: I am just learning to notice the different colors of the stars, and already begin to have a new enjoyment.

title: The Best Gift
subject: Confirmation
content: For my confirmation, I didn't get a watch and my first pair of long pants, like most Lutheran boys. I got a telescope. My mother thought it would make the best gift.

title: The Call
subject: Five Senses
content: Equipped with his five senses, man explores the universe around him and calls the adventure Science.

title: Too Intelligent
subject: The Universe
content: I'm sure the universe is full of intelligent life. It's just been too intelligent to come here.

title: The Cosmos
subject: Feeblest Contemplations
content: The cosmos is all that is or ever was or ever will be. Our feeblest contemplations of the Cosmos stir us—there is a tingling in the spine, a catch in the voice, a faint sensation, as if a distant memory, or falling from a height. We know we are approaching the greatest of mysteries.

title: The Cosmos II
subject: Was or Ever Will Be
content: If it’s a new planet, sign me up. I’m tired of driving around the block, boldly going where hundreds have gone before in orbit around earth--give me a place to go and I’ll go.

title: The Confine
subject: Terrestrial Matters
content: To confine our attention to terrestrial matters would be to limit the human spirit.

title: Grasp
subject: Far Better
content: It is far better to grasp the universe as it really is than to persist in delusion, however satisfying and reassuring.

title: Can Bind
subject: Reconcile
content: If there is anything that can bind the heavenly mind of man to this dreary exile of our earthly home and can reconcile us with our fate so that one can enjoy living, then it is verily the enjoyment of the mathematical sciences and astronomy.

title: Humbling
subject: Character Builder
content: It's been said that astronomy is a humbling and, I might add, a character-building experience.

title: No Boundary
subject: Condition
content: The boundary condition of the universe is that is has no boundary.

title: Tiny Pea
subject: Very Small
content: It suddenly struck me that that tiny pea, pretty and blue, was the earth. I put up my thumb and shut one eye, and my thumb blotted out the planet earth. I didn’t feel like a giant. I felt very, very small.

title: Indifferent
subject: Not Benign Nor Hostile
content: The universe seems neither benign nor hostile, merely indifferent.

title: No Where
subject: How the Heavens Go
content: The Bible tells us how to go to Heaven, not how the heavens go.

title: Center of All
subject: Beautiful Temple
content: In the center of all rests the Sun. For who would place this lamp of a very beautiful temple in another or better place than this from which it can illuminate everything at the same time.

title: Never Lie
subject: Ahem
content: The stars never lie, but the astrologers lie about the stars.

title: The Knowledge
subject: Light Elements
content: The knowledge that the atoms that comprise life on earth - the atoms that make up the human body, are traceable to the crucibles that cooked light elements into heavy elements in their core under extreme temperatures and pressures. These stars- the high mass ones among them- went unstable in their later years- they collapsed and then exploded- scattering their enriched guts across the galaxy- guts made of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, and all the fundamental ingredients of life itself. These ingredients become part of gas clouds that condense, collapse, form the next generation of solar systems- stars with orbiting planets. And those planets now have the ingredients for life itself. So that when I look up at the night sky, and I know that yes we are part of this universe, we are in this universe, but perhaps more important than both of those facts is that the universe is in us. When I reflect on that fact, I look up- many people feel small, cause their small and the universe is big. But I feel big because my atoms came from those stars.

title: Put to Use
subject: The Force
content: Discover the force of the skies O Men: once recognised it can be put to use.

title: One Focus
subject: Ellipses
content: Planets move in ellipses with the Sun at one focus.
